intro: Sida rohlenae var. mutica, commonly known as the rough sida, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and small, yellowish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in disturbed soils and is often found in desert scrub and grassland habitats. Its fibrous stem and serrated leaves are adapted to conserve water in harsh environments. Sida rohlenae var. mutica is also known for its role in supporting local insect populations and its potential use in traditional medicine.
